channel.title: User accounts on windows XP
channel.description:
First off, [u][i][b]I KNOW THAT THIS IS NOT RELATED TO MOPAR BUT I DON'T KNOW WHERE ELSE TO POST IT![/b][/i][/u]
Now, my question is:
Well, when you have windows xp you have user accounts (like this):
[IMG]http://i1031.photobucket.com/albums/y380/mrpopyman/user1.jpg[/img] [IMG]http://i1031.photobucket.com/albums/y380/mrpopyman/user2.jpg[/img]
and u can edit account like this:
[IMG]http://i1031.photobucket.com/albums/y380/mrpopyman/user3.jpg[/img]
and you log in like this:
[img]http://fc03.deviantart.net/fs70/i/2010/163/b/5/Win_7_Login_Screen_for_Vista_by_Vishal_Gupta.png[/img]
but what i wanna know, is how do you make it so you have to type in your username and pass? (like this):
[img]http://www.kltforums.net/hosted/images/rdc_fig3.jpg[/img]
someone help? please?!!
Again: [u][i][b]I KNOW THAT THIS IS NOT RELATED TO MOPAR BUT I DON'T KNOW WHERE ELSE TO POST IT![/b][/i][/u]

item.title: User accounts on windows XP
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“LilXCj, post:30, topic:409206”]So, you want it to act like you’re at school? With the login interface?[/quote]Any company with more than 5 employees probably uses a log in system like this

Read full topic

item.title: User accounts on windows XP
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

LilXCj:

So, you want it to act like you’re at school? With the login interface?

Implying good schools only run Windows.

I always use the ‘classic’ login interface, it’s much cleaner and more secure.

Read full topic

item.title: User accounts on windows XP
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Fat Cookies:

Just go to Control Panel > Accounts and somewhere in there gives you the option to change login screens.

Just realized we were talking about windows XP here - disable fast user switching and the other options presented in the ‘change the way users login’ interface.

Read full topic

item.title: User accounts on windows XP
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Just go to Control Panel > Accounts and somewhere in there gives you the option to change login screens.

Read full topic

item.title: User accounts on windows XP
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

yes which is the only way to require u to enter both username and password. its for either added security or use on domain logins. its used in all the schools ive been to. i actually use this on my laptop which the login is quite different than xp graphic and option-wise.

if you know of a way better then this i would like to know so i can have more knowledge but i think thats just the way microsoft made it.

Read full topic

item.title: User accounts on windows XP
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

xryz:

go to ur start menu, click “run”, type in the text box “control userpasswords2” without quotes hit enter. then go to the advanced tab, there should be something like secure login make sure that check box is checked. idk how it looks on xp since i have windows 7 but it should be very similar to that. u can also do this by changing local policies within control panel > administrative tools > local security policies(im not 100% sure). this doesnt have alot but here it is http://www.microsoft.com/resources/documentation/windows/xp/all/proddocs/en-us/loc_sec_set.mspx?mfr=true i dont suggest messing with local security policies unless u know what u are doing.

But that will force him to press CTRL-ALT-DELETE?

Read full topic

item.title: User accounts on windows XP
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

go to ur start menu, click “run”, type in the text box “control userpasswords2” without quotes hit enter. then go to the advanced tab, there should be something like secure login make sure that check box is checked. idk how it looks on xp since i have windows 7 but it should be very similar to that. u can also do this by changing local policies within control panel > administrative tools > local security policies(im not 100% sure). this doesnt have alot but here it is http://www.microsoft.com/resources/documentation/windows/xp/all/proddocs/en-us/loc_sec_set.mspx?mfr=true i dont suggest messing with local security policies unless u know what u are doing.

Read full topic

item.title: User accounts on windows XP
item.dc:creator: @mcbeans mcbeans
item.description:
@mcbeans wrote:

i do not wish to troll on this page any longer, (or at all) so i would like someone to lock this topic already before cole shows his true feelings.

[quote=“mrpopyman, post:15, topic:409206”][quote author=Cole1497 link=topic=510485.msg3704383#msg3704383 date=1312939365]

You’re not specific. Are you saying you want a password on your account?

no, i want to change the way i log in from this:

to this:

this… is a troll, cole has obviously fallen for the troll because he is ignorant /thread

im not troll, you are

then obviously you are too ignorant to notice that your operating system is windows 7 not xp and is therefore irreversibly like that. and also there is a general help section in which you could acquire help from other people not an ignorant blowhard like cole.

Ouch, that’s effective.
[/quote]

MY COMPUTER IS NOT WINDOWS 7!![/quote]
you are not an effective troll.

Read full topic
